w:r.w:t: This lesson will focus on the home and different objects and furniture that are in the home. Spelling words will be introduced to the student, and they will soon be able to comprehend the basics of words structure and spelling phonetics.
At the completion of this lesson, students will be able to:
Recognize, spell, and pronounce the words for different objects and places in a home.
Spell and pronounce commonly associated words and actions
home, bed, table, desk, lamp, chair, couch, bedroom, living room, kitchen, bathroom, microwave, toaster, oven,
This slide will always be the
-branded opener slide that the teacher will display as the student enters the classroom.
Greet your student and introduce the lesson concept: Today, we are going to be learning the different rooms and objects that might be in our house.
Draw a picture of what my home looks like.
Provide a picture of your own (or a sample picture) home for students.
. Point to self at “my” and point to the picture at “home”.
Visual cue: Have students draw a picture of what their homes look like.
What does your home look like?
Be sure to point to student when you say “your” and the picture of the house on the screen when saying “house.”
Have students try to describe their home using the following sentence frames:
. (i.e. red, big, windows, a door, etc.)
List the different rooms that are in my house.
on the screen. Have student repeat and write word on screen or on a separate piece of paper.
Ask students to list the different rooms that they have in their house. This will establish background knowledge if student knows what the different rooms in a house is called.
Explain to students that all homes are different and may have different rooms.
Have students use the sentence frame
One room in my home is the ________
Draw a picture of what my bedroom looks like.
. Ask student to repeat the word and write it.
. Point to yourself when you say “my” and point to an example of a bedroom when you say the word “bedroom.”
Visual Cue: Have students draw an example of their bedroom. Encourage students to list different objects they may have in their bedroom to determine background knowledge.
Match the correct sight word with the item in the picture
Complete the sentence frame: In my bedroom, I have a ______________
Visual cues: point out objects that may be available to you in the classroom (i.e. desk, chair, lamp).
Ask students to circle objects that they have in their bedroom.
Any objects that are in their bedroom that are not shown here, have students draw.
Draw a picture of what my living room looks like.
. Ask student to repeat the word and write it.
. Point to yourself when you say “my” and point to an example of a living room when you say the word “living room.”
Visual Cue: Have student draw an example of their living room. Encourage students to list different objects they may have in their living room to determine background knowledge.
Match the correct sight word with the item in the picture
Complete the sentence frame: In my living room, I have a couch.
Ask students to circle objects that they have in their living room.
Any objects that are in their living room that are not shown here, have students draw or explain.
In my living room, I have a _________
to help them in their conversation.
Draw a picture of what my kitchen looks like.
. Ask student to repeat the word and write it.
. Point to yourself when you say “my” and point to an example of a kitchen when you say the word “kitchen.”
Visual Cue: Have student draw an example of their kitchen. Encourage students to list different objects they may have in their kitchen to determine background knowledge.
Match the correct sight word with the item in the picture
Complete the sentence frame: In my
Have students repeat both actions. Explain to students that a stove is also called an
Ask students to circle objects that they have in their kitchen.
Any objects that are in their kitchen that are not shown here, have students draw or explain.
In my kitchen, I have a _________
to help them in their conversation.
Draw a picture of what my bathroom looks like.
. Ask student to repeat the word and write it.
. Point to yourself when you say “my” and point to an example of a bathroom when you say the word “bathroom.”
Visual Cue: Have student draw an example of their bathroom. Encourage students to list different objects they may have in their bathroom to determine background knowledge.
Match the correct sight word with the item in the picture
Complete the sentence frame: In my
Ask students to circle objects that they have in their bathroom.
Any objects that are in their bathroom that are not shown here, have students draw or explain.
In my bathroom, I have a _________
to help them in their conversation.
Complete the sentence frame: I am __________.
Prompt the student to recall the name of the room: kitchen
Visual cue: Show student the action for “eating” (mimic holding a fork or spoon and putting it up to your mouth). Have student do the action as they get to “eating” when they say the phrase.
Complete the sentence frame: I am __________.
Prompt the student to recall the name of the room:

Visual cue: Show student the action for “sleeping” (mimic holding hands in a “prayer” position on the side of one cheek and tilt head; snore; close eyes). Have students do the action when they get to “sleeping” in the phrase.
Complete the sentence frame: I am __________.
Prompt the student to recall the name of the room:
Visual cue: Show student the action for “cooking” (mimic stirring a bowl, flipping a pancake, chopping vegetables, etc.) Have students do the action when they get to “cooking” in the phrase.

Circle the picture of the boy. Ask students to say what the boy is doing by selecting the correct answer. Students can instead use these actions instead of speaking their answer: one finger (sleeping), two fingers (eating), three fingers (cooking).
Have the child say their answer in a complete sentence:
Prompt the student to recall the name of the room:

Circle the picture of the girl. Ask students to say what the girl is doing by selecting the correct answer. Students can instead use these actions instead of speaking their answer: one finger (sleeping), two fingers (eating), three fingers (cooking).
Have the child say their answer in a complete sentence:
Prompt the student to recall the name of the room:

Circle the picture of the family. Ask students to say what they are doing by selecting the correct answer. Students can instead use these actions instead of speaking their answer: one finger (sleeping), two fingers (eating), three fingers (cooking).
Have the child say their answer in a complete sentence:

Freeform “Show and Tell” Conversation Activity Slide 21
Students should have a blank slide to draw a picture of different house objects or rooms on teacher prompts.
, bed, table, desk, lamp, chair, couch, bedroom, living room, kitchen, bathroom, microwave, toaster, oven, refrigerator,
Teacher will prompt student to draw a picture to represent different activities through pictures. One prompt at a time.
Teacher will write words from the lesson
, bed, table, desk, lamp, chair, couch, bedroom, living room, kitchen, bathroom, microwave, toaster, oven, refrigerator,
Students will read and spell their new words: (home, bed, table, desk, lamp, chair, couch, bedroom, living room, kitchen, bathroom, microwave, toaster, oven, refrigerator,
Teacher will give feedback on the spelling and pronunciation of the new words.
